data.title: Avalanche 201: The Institutional Platform
data.description:
This piece explores Avalanche’s second act as the network shifts toward becoming institutional-grade blockchain infrastructure for tokenization, payments, and real-world financial systems.

Please note that VanEck may have a position(s) in the digital asset(s) described below.

Key takeaways:

  • Avalanche is a high-speed, multi-chain platform: It is a system of many blockchains designed to solve scalability issues by allowing applications to run on their own dedicated, purpose-built networks.
  • Enterprise adoption anchors long-term value: Major financial institutions such as J.P. Morgan, Apollo, and Citi are using Avalanche for real-world asset tokenization and backend infrastructure.
  • Strategic pricing shift drives network activity: Recent fee reductions have successfully sparked growth in daily active users and transaction volume, positioning the network for broader mainstream adoption.

Introduction to Avalanche

Avalanche (AVAX-USD) is a high-performance platform that powers a network of interconnected, customizable blockchains. It has attracted both crypto-native users and enterprises, with Avalanche L1s processing about 40M transactions per day and supporting roughly 38M daily active users across 81 active blockchains. Avalanche has also brought $1.4B of real-world asset value onchain through institutions such as BlackRock, Janus Henderson, Franklin Templeton, and Republic. These teams are drawn to Avalanche’s predictable performance and scaling model built to support tens of millions of future users.

From the start, Avalanche was built around different priorities than many legacy blockchains. Rather than centering the “digital gold” narrative, Avalanche focused on performance and scale, pioneering a novel consensus design and a multi-chain architecture. After launching in 2020, early adoption came from crypto-native users who wanted a faster alternative to Ethereum (ETH-USD). Avalanche still maintains meaningful activity in DeFi and gaming, but it has increasingly evolved into a leading platform for custom Layer 1 blockchains, real-world asset tokenization, and enterprise deployment.

Today, Avalanche focuses on enterprise, financial institution, and public sector use cases through its “AvaCloud” offering. The goal is to operate as a scalable, reliable backend infrastructure while preserving the core benefits of blockchain: transparency, fast settlement, and interoperability.

We believe Avalanche’s long-term opportunity depends on whether it can convert enterprise interest into sustained production deployments. Progress to date is encouraging, even if broad adoption is still in its early stages. Overall, Avalanche offers investors differentiated exposure to a “suit and tie” platform that is working to bring large organizations onchain.

Avalanche Design for Rapid Consensus: Snowman

Avalanche offers a key breakthrough called the “Snowman Consensus.” Consensus is the method by which a chain agrees on blocks, and Avalanche’s innovation is to implement a more efficient, faster polling technique between validators. This allows it to produce blocks at a faster rate with more transaction capacity in each block than Ethereum.

On legacy blockchains, this means far more communication than necessary, slowing block processing time. By contrast, Avalanche does not have a fixed “leader,” and instead allows any validator to propose blocks from the transactions they observe. Avalanche validators then ping one another in small, randomly selected groups to conduct repeated polls on the correct ledger and its content. Validators repeat these small-group polls until they have enough mathematical confidence that their view has finalized, and the network will converge on the same ledger.

The result of this process is that Avalanche can process a block every 1.2 seconds, and the transactions within each block are considered “final” almost instantly. Avalanche competitor Ethereum produces blocks every 12 seconds while finality takes around 12.8 minutes. This allows Avalanche users to recognize settlement of their transactions within a few seconds, giving the chain significant practical advantages for financial use cases.

Avalanche’s Multi-Chain Architecture

Avalanche is not a single blockchain but a system composed of many blockchains built using Avalanche’s software. There are 81 live blockchains in the ecosystem, with hundreds more in development. Each Avalanche L1 can bootstrap its own validators or use core validators operating on Avalanche’s primary chains. Many L1s also modify Avalanche’s core software to tailor performance, governance, and functionality, including cross-chain connections to other Avalanche L1s and to the Avalanche C-Chain. Some L1s are public while others are private and permissioned.

The Avalanche Primary Network comprises the three original Avalanche chains. These are the C, P, and X chains. While the C-Chain is the epicenter of Avalanche’s crypto activity, the P-Chain is the network that coordinates Avalanche’s validators. The X-chain is currently only used to mint inflationary AVAX tokens. Each of these chains uses AVAX as the native token for payments and usage.

The Avalanche C-Chain is the most economically valuable blockchain in the Avalanche ecosystem and, on average, processes $528M in economic activity each day. It uses the Ethereum Virtual Machine, which allows Avalanche developers to use the same smart contract language and tooling used to build Ethereum applications. Thus, Ethereum developers can quickly deploy their applications to Avalanche with only a few tweaks. In practice, this opened the aperture for new entrants to the Avalanche ecosystem by tapping into a huge pool of potential builders.

The C-Chain offers economic and scaling advantages over Ethereum. It can process (+88%) more transaction throughput (measured by gas) while pricing transactions at 1/50ththe cost of Ethereum’s fees. Avalanche also has the unique ability to rapidly increase its block size during periods of high demand, meaning that Avalanche’s throughput advantage grows during stressful periods.

Outside of the Primary Network, an L1 with notable traction is Binary Holdings, which runs a rewards and loyalty program for South Asian telecommunications firms. It reports 36M daily active addresses and roughly 40M transactions per day, reflecting a “blockchain-as-infrastructure” thesis where end users may not even realize they are interacting with a blockchain.

Another is Dexalot L1, designed to provide centralized-exchange-like speed and capacity while preserving onchain transparency. Dexalot operates a dual-chain setup: users bridge and deposit via Avalanche C-Chain and execute trades on a customized L1 optimized for large trading volumes.

Enterprise Adoption for Traditional Finance and Tokenization

Avalanche has launched public pilots for private markets tokenization with well-known traditional finance participants. For example, Apollo tokenized a $50M credit fund on Avalanche in January 2026. Avalanche has also pursued distribution-oriented partnerships aligned with enterprise requirements, including AWS support for government-oriented deployment and compliance pathways.

Deloitte has used Avalanche to create a platform intended to improve the speed, security, and accuracy of FEMA reimbursements following disasters. These examples highlight the direction of travel: Avalanche is positioning itself as infrastructure that can plug into real workflows, not just crypto-native applications.

Avalanche has key advantages over competing blockchains, but a practical question is: “Why would someone want to deploy an Avalanche L1 instead of an Ethereum L2?”

Service and accountability

Avalanche offers builders a dedicated, for-profit engineering organization, Ava Labs, that can provide direct support, implementation assistance, and customization in a way that feels closer to a SaaS vendor relationship. Ethereum has excellent vendors and L2 teams, but creating an L2 on Ethereum typically requires a builder to choose a team with an opinionated framework. In some cases, those Ethereum L2 consultants may also push design decisions that benefit their own economic model rather than the builder’s.

Sovereign chain design

An Avalanche L1 is a sovereign network where the deployer can set rules, define execution, and choose the virtual machine. That flexibility matters when an application or use case cannot be implemented within the EVM's limits, or when the builder needs to tune governance and performance for a specific workflow.

Operational and compliance flexibility

Avalanche offers SOC 2 certified infrastructure that supports enterprise-grade security, with options for compliant operations in regulated sectors. An enterprise can define validator requirements, including hardware standards and participation restrictions tied to governance or compliance. In practice, this can be harder to replicate on Ethereum L2s without adding extra trust assumptions around sequencers, committees, or bespoke bridging.

Enterprise-friendly economics

Avalanche L1s can define their own fee markets and use the token of their choice, meaning they do not need to use AVAX for gas. Operating costs are also easier for enterprises to budget because they are tied more directly to the validator footprint than to fluctuating usage. Avalanche’s L1 validator fee model is structured as an ongoing charge to run validators, whereas Ethereum is closer to a pay-as-you-go business arrangement. As a result, Avalanche L1s can feel more like SaaS licensing models with costs that scale with deployment requirements rather than short-term demand spikes. This makes the costs for Avalanche L1 operators more predictable.

Risk and performance isolation

Ethereum L2s ultimately inherit key constraints from Ethereum, especially around settlement back to L1 and the specific rollup's design choices. For example, optimistic rollup L2s have built-in delay periods for withdrawals that would prevent L2 users from quickly withdrawing funds. Additionally, Ethereum L2 can still experience congestion if Ethereum Mainnet is overloaded with activity.

Because Avalanche L1s isolate performance and fees from other chains, enterprises can avoid congestion problems caused by unrelated activity. Also, Avalanche L1s can adjust throughput, latency, and governance to fit the needs of the application.

Simplicity of deployment

Avalanche has built the tooling and support to allow potential developers to quickly create Avalanche blockchains. In fact, builders without deep coding experience can create an Avalanche L1 without code and deploy it within minutes. Because Avalanche offers cross-chain support out of the box, sophisticated developers can create dozens of blockchains that act in concert to meet their needs.

Key partnerships

  1. Cloud and infrastructure partners for lowering the operational friction of operating Avalanche blockchains or using Avalanche blockchains,

Partners: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Alibaba Cloud, Tencent Cloud.

  1. Public sector and government process partners modernizing heavy workflows, improving auditability, and reducing fraud and administrative overhead in government adjacent processes.

Partners: Deloitte and the California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV).

  1. Payments and onboarding partners that reduce the adoption bottleneck for users and mainstream applications, allowing them to quickly get funds onchain while abiding by compliance rules.

Partners: Stripe, Mastercard, Visa

  1. Capital markets, banking, and institutional tokenization partners to prove Avalanche’s potential to operate backend infrastructure for major financial institutions, including tokenization, fund operations, and credit market infrastructure.

Partners: Sumitomo Corporation, FIS and Intain, Citi and Wellington Management and WisdomTree and ABN AMRO and DTCC Digital Assets and Tokeny, J.P. Morgan Onyx and Apollo and WisdomTree and LayerZero, Securitize.

  1. Commerce and consumer distribution partners that see digital assets and onchain experiences as additive to customer acquisition and retention.

Partners: FIFA, Uptop, Sports Illustrated, EVEN, TITAN

The corporate partnerships in this blog reflect the use of the Avalanche network and do not imply endorsement of AVAX as an investment.

Avalanche C-Chain Revenue

The AVAX token is the “native token” of all Avalanche blockchains but is most used on Avalanche’s C-Chain. This means that all transactions on that network necessitate AVAX to be processed. Because the C-Chain’s capacity for transactions is limited, as the level of activity increases, the amount of AVAX needed to transact rises as well. Like Ethereum, Avalanche also implements an economic policy that burns base fees to offset inflation. As Avalanche transaction velocity increases, more AVAX tokens are burned, and the total can be enormous during times of high activity. To date, 4.9M AVAX has been permanently removed from circulation.

The current supply of AVAX is 431M, while the maximum supply of the token is 720M. To reach the maximum supply of AVAX, Avalanche mints new tokens to reward validators and stakers for running and securing the network. The current inflation rate for new AVAX tokens is (~3.5%) per year, and the number of new tokens emitted fluctuates based on the number of AVAX staked and their staking duration.

Because Avalanche is a Proof-of-Stake (PoS) blockchain, AVAX is used to back validators who run and secure Avalanche’s C-Chain. Each validator must be backed by a minimum of 2,000 AVAX “bond” to operate on the blockchain, but in practice, validator stakes are often much larger because larger validators can receive more rewards (up to 3M AVAX). To satisfy the bonding requirement, validators often source AVAX bonds from tokenholders seeking to earn rewards on their AVAX holdings. However, validators who are dishonest or who demonstrate poor uptime can lose their access to rewards or even be booted from the network. This economic incentive drives stakers to seek high-quality validators.

The current reward rate for Avalanche stakers is (>7%), which is greater than the rate of inflation because not all AVAX tokens on Avalanche are staked. To stake on Avalanche, someone must bond a minimum of 25 AVAX and choose the duration of their lock-up. Those who choose to delegate their AVAX to a validator for longer periods receive higher rewards than those who opt for shorter bonding periods.

Outside of Avalanche C-Chain, validators of other Avalanche L1s must pay a per-validator fee of 1.33 AVAX per month. These fees are burned. With ~850 L1 validators, this amounts to $160k in annual revenue.

The Bear and Bull Case for AVAX

The Bear Case: Declining Metrics and Competitive Pressures

Currently, Avalanche is at a crossroads, making some bearish about its future. Once a member of the “SOLUNAVAX” triad meme spawned by immense returns in the summer of 2021 (>+1000% returns in 4 months), AVAX has lost (-62%) of its value in the past year. Aside from broad, weak alt-token performance (MarketVector Smart Contract Leaders Index: -37% y/y), competitive pressures have driven Avalanche to reduce its transaction pricing on the C-Chain by (-96%). This has led to a (-42%) y/y reduction in revenues.

Avalanche onchain metrics have also generally lagged those of its competitors. Revenue has fallen to 13th in the 30-day trailing period, down from 8th place 2 years ago and 4th place 4 years ago. In TVL, over the past four years, it has dropped from the 3rd-ranked blockchain to the 7th-ranked blockchain.

At the same time, there is concern that Avalanche L1s do not remit enough value to AVAX because they have little use in their frameworks. This is due to the lack of requirement to use AVAX as a native token on Avalanche L1s. Previously, Avalanche L1s (formerly 'Subnets') were required to stake 2,000 AVAX per validator, but this requirement was nixed, removing a major token sink for AVAX.

Potential risks

  1. Competition from other blockchains
  2. Value of blockchain technologies accruing to existing financial institutions
  3. Emerging blockchains offering better technology
  4. Regulation of DeFi
  5. Increase in the inflation rate or expansion of the token supply
  6. Technical risks and hacking attacks
  7. Potential risks related to team dynamics and strategic priorities of core developers

The Bull Case: Pivot to Enterprise and Ecosystem Growth

However, it is important to remember that investors valuing tokens like AVAX must look to the future, not Avalanche’s past identity. Avalanche technology was initially used to facilitate speculation, and it was presumed that this would evolve towards more sustainable financial products and services. However, the speculative narrative has evaporated as systematically overvalued cryptocurrencies failed to mature into more sustainable use cases. At the same time, existing financial institutions began adopting the most promising components of crypto to navigate many blockchain ecosystems effectively. As a result, Avalanche is moving towards enterprise use cases and real-world assets to build the products that can attract corporate interest. In this enterprise-centric new vision, Avalanche is an absolute leader compared to most other crypto projects.

Avalanche’s new approach to long-term token holder value is to bring as many users as possible into its network of blockchains. This includes substantial price decreases alongside marketing focus on Avalanche L1s. Thus, one can view its price decreases as an opportunity to attract new users and expand use cases. Once Avalanche has proved its value to a large user base, it is presumed to be able to capture more value from its blockchain’s activity. Thus far, some of the steps to attract new activity have been working.

The deliberate choice to reduce C-Chain fees has led to transactions growing (+370%) and (DAAS) surging (+368%) y/y. Likewise, Avalanche L1 outreach has attracted nearly 4M DAAs to Avalanche’s L1s (2-3x more DAUs than Ethereum’s ecosystem), collectively generating ~$25k in fees per day. At the same time, tokenization efforts have led to $1.4B in assets on Avalanche through partnerships with some of the world’s most important financial institutions. If Avalanche can continue to prove itself as an important backend financial infrastructure, it stands to benefit greatly from tokenization.

Potential catalysts

  1. Tokenization is increasing usership and usage of the Avalanche blockchains
  2. Re-institution Avalanche L1 validator AVAX holding requirements
  3. AVAX native token being adopted by Avalanche L1s
  4. Avalanche’s growing gaming system is driving wallet growth
  5. The launch of high-velocity financial products
  6. Additional Avalanche L1 launches

The Token vs Contributor Interests Debate

A key consideration for AVAX, as with many smart contract platforms, is the relationship between the token and the organizations that materially contribute to the ecosystem’s development and commercialization. Ava Labs is a major contributor to Avalanche’s core software and provides services to teams building on Avalanche technology. As a for-profit company, Ava Labs will make business decisions around resourcing, pricing, partnerships, and product focus based on its own operational needs and stakeholder obligations, which may not always align perfectly with the preferences of AVAX holders.

That said, the linkage is indirect. Ava Labs does not control AVAX’s market price, and Avalanche’s open-source ecosystem includes many independent developers and participants. Over time, successful ecosystem growth, whether through C-Chain activity or application-specific L1s, can support network usage and broader awareness, which may be constructive for the asset.

From a risk perspective, the main issues are practical rather than mechanical. If key ecosystem contributors were to face operational disruption, such as funding constraints, strategic shifts, or other business pressures, the pace of development, ecosystem support, or market confidence could be affected. Conversely, a well-capitalized, execution-oriented contributor base can help Avalanche remain competitive. We therefore view Ava Labs as a net positive for Avalanche today, while recognizing that AVAX’s long-term outcome ultimately depends on adoption and the broader ecosystem, not any single company.

Avalanche Leadership Team

Emin Gün Sirer - CEO

Computer scientist and co-founder who helped create the Avalanche consensus approach and leads the technical direction of Ava Labs. He is also a Cornell computer science professor and has held leadership roles in academic crypto research, including as a co-director of IC3.

John Wu - President

Leads commercial strategy, business development, and partnerships. Before Ava Labs, he built his career as a buy-side tech investor, including at Tiger Management, and later ran investment and operating roles across fintech, including leading Sureview Capital and managing a technology portfolio at Kingdon Capital.

Charley Cooper - Chief Operating Officer

Runs operations with deep experience across market structure and regulation. Previously served in senior leadership at the CFTC and held senior roles in financial markets infrastructure, including at State Street’s trading and clearing organization, with earlier experience at Deutsche Bank.

John Nahas – Chief Business Officer

Leads business development and ecosystem growth for Ava Labs and the Avalanche network, overseeing partnerships and go-to-market across multiple verticals (including institutional/capital markets, enterprise, wallets & exchanges, retail/consumer, gaming, and DeFi) and driving international expansion through regional teams globally.

Wee Ming Choon - Chief Legal Officer

Leads legal and regulatory strategy with a rare combination of software engineering and law. Prior to Ava Labs, his background includes roles at major tech and crypto-native organizations, including Meta and ConsenSys, as well as private practice at Latham & Watkins.

The Bottom Line on Avalanche's Value Proposition

Overall, we recognize the conflict embedded in Avalanche’s structure, but we believe the value Ava Labs provides to AVAX holders outweighs these concerns, especially if the scaling strategy succeeds and AVAX’s role in value capture strengthens over time.

data.title: SIVR: The Cheapest ETF Proxy On Physical Silver
data.description:
Introduction To The abrdn Physical Silver Shares ETF

The abrdn Physical Silver Shares ETF (SIVR), which made its debut on the markets on July 20, 2009, has so far accumulated total assets under management of over $6.6B. SIVR, which belongs to Aberdeen Group PLC (a UK-based investment manager), is issued by the latter’s wholly-owned subsidiary- abrdn ETFs Sponsor LLC [AESL]. To procure a stake in SIVR, investors will need to pay an expense ratio of 0.3%. SIVR does not make any dividends.

What Does SIVR Do?

SIVR’s chief purpose it to serve as an accessible and cost-efficient vehicle for those who want to profit from the movement of physical silver prices (and not silver futures). SIVR, is basically the owner of 75.4m troy ounces of physical silver bullion bars, which are stored and maintained in secured vaults in the UK.

Also consider that rather than being set up as an investment company that resorts to active management strategies to generate returns, SIVR is structured as a grantor trust. This means the onus here is to just hold the physical silver and issue shares against it (which investors buy, giving them fractional ownership of the entire silver held), rather than selling the metal when it goes higher, or purchasing it when it dips, or enhancing returns through the use of derivative contracts, etc.

Who Are the Main Parties Within SIVR’s Setup?

Behind SIVR’s successful operations there are a number of key parties that are worth noting:

  • Sponsor: As covered in the initial section of this article, this role is carried out by AESL, whose responsibility is to create and register shares of SIVR on the NYSE Arca, and issue new shares when required. AESL can be construed to be the general manager of this set-up and is also responsible for picking other key parties (as described below) that are essential to the running of SIVR.
  • Custodian: The silver bars that SIVR holds aren’t held by the sponsor, but by a custodian called ICBC Standard Bank PLC [ISBP]. Interestingly ISBP only took over custodianship responsibilities of SIVR in May 2024 [before that custodianship duties were carried out by JP Morgan Chase] who parks them in their London vaults.
  • Trustee: Trusteeship is carried out by the Bank of New York Mellon Corporation (BK) that looks into the day-to-day administrative work (calculation of the daily NAV, accounting entries, creating grantor trust tax information, etc.)
  • Metal inspector: To ensure that the quality of the bullion bars held in the vaults doesn’t disintegrate, the services of Bureau Veritas Commodities UK Ltd (BVRDF), is also tapped twice a year. Besides a standard inspection at the end of the year, the first inspection takes place on a random date during the year.

What Are the Risks Associated With SIVR?

Since SIVR is established as a grantor trust that holds physical metal, it exhibits some tax inefficiencies that may be seen as cumbersome to a fair few. For instance, long-term capital gains [LTCG] are taxed at a higher collectibles rate of 28% rather than 20% LTCG rate.

In addition to that, because SIVR is a grantor trust, it does not pay any income tax, with all tax liabilities flowing through to its investors. Also, we know this trust has various expenses to incur, but because there’s no income coming in to cover those expenses, a fraction of the silver owned needs to be sold every month to meet those expenses (also existing holders of SIVR own less silver every month, as a pro-rate share of their holdings been cashed in every month to meet those expenses). Also, even though there is some disposition of investors’ assets every month, the proceeds don’t come to investors’ accounts, yet they are charged with a capital gain or loss and don’t receive a tax break for the same either. This facet could prove to be particularly troubling to those who own SIVR in taxable brokerage accounts (as opposed to IRA or 401(k)s)).

While silver does exhibit shades of a safe haven when risk sentiment in the markets dip or geopolitical risks spike, this defensive trait certainly isn’t as pronounced as gold. Also, silver’s prospects are closely tied to the health of global industrials, making this quite a risky bet that could face some pressure during global cyclical downswings. Investors should also consider that unlike diversified ETFs, SIVR is a single-commodity ETF, which certainly elevates its risk profile. This can be validated even further by SIVR’s standard deviation and volatility readings which are roughly 3x more than a standard ETF, making this product unsuitable for investors with conservative risk appetite.

Silver has an inverse relationship with the US Dollar, so if the latter witnesses meaningful appreciation, this could be detrimental for SIVR.

Silver has benefited through multi-year deficits (including 2026, we will see will be six straight years of deficits), but investors should also note that these deficits are shrinking by the year (for instance FY25’s estimated deficit of 95-149Moz, is poised to shrink to 68Moz this year) and in a few years, there’s potential for the market position to normalize, which ultimately won’t reflect well on prices.

If investors are thinking of pursuing SIVR with the intention of also procuring a quarterly, semi-annual or annual dividend bonus (which is standard practice with most ETFs today), then this isn’t the right product. The holdings (equities, bonds, derivative contracts) in most ETFs usually generate some form of income, or are sometimes lent out, to earn additional income, which is then passed on to these shareholders by way of distributions, but in SIVR’s case, it just plainly holds physical silver, and its returns are just a function of the price movements of silver (and nothing more) after accounting for trust expenses.

Investors should also note that SIVR hasn’t taken out an insurance policy to cover its silver holdings; insurance support if any, only comes in the form of the insurance that the custodian-ISBP, has taken for its entire operation (and not just the silver it holds for SIVR).

Who Is SIVR For?

SIVR is meant for those who want a cost-efficient and transparent route to owning physical silver. For further context note that, SIVR’s expense ratio of 0.3% is already 20bps lower than the median expense ratio of all ETFs.

Facilitating such a low expense ratio in the silver space is not easy to come by, with competing products priced at a much higher range of 0.5-0.95% (admittedly, some of these products are leveraged ETFs which will understandably cost more, but even against the unleveraged ETFs SIVR has a strong edge).

SIVR also scores high on transparency, with its custodian- ISBP, providing a bar list which is updated every day.

Investors attracted to SIVR are typically also those who are likely feeling emboldened about the long-term health and the buoyancy of the global industrial landscape; after all, roughly 60% of silver demand comes from the industrial sector.

Within industrials, those who expect the solar wave to gain traction will like this product, as modern solar cells are increasingly seeing higher silver paste per cells than older models. Also, if investors are big on growing electrification of the modern world, a position in SIVR would represent a good bet, as silver is the most conductive metal around.

SIVR would also be suitable for those who expect the debasement and devaluation of fiat currencies.

SIVR and silver would also represent a good diversifier for US equity-heavy portfolios; we say this because over the last decade, the price of silver has exhibited relatively low correlation (less than 0.25x) with the US equity benchmark- the S&P 500.

Peers Of SIVR

If not for SIVR, investors who want unleveraged ETF access to physical silver could also look at the iShares Silver Trust (SLV) or the Sprott Physical Silver Trust (PSLV).

SLV is the most established product out of the lot, with a trading history that goes back to April 2006 (whereas PSLV got listed around 15 months after SIVR in October 2010). Relative longevity certainly appears to have played a part in the respective AUMs of these products, although SLV is well ahead of the other two at nearly $50B of AUM. SLV’s strong drawing power can also be felt through the liquidity it attracts every day (around $8B of dollar volumes, whereas the other two see less than half a billion dollars).

PSLV, which is the priciest out of the lot (expense ratio of 0.57%), is meant for those also want the option of redeeming their stake through physical silver (and not just cash). Both SLV and SIVR don’t have this useful redemption option. It must also be said that for the degree of AUM it has accumulated, PSLV sees very strong daily liquidity (almost half its total AUM). In addition to that, PSLV is set up as a Canadian trust, and thus the IRS recognizes it as a Passive Foreign Investment Corporation (PFIC). The benefit of this is that long-term capital gains could be a lot lower at 15-20%, rather than the 28% rate that the other two alternatives are subject to.

Summary

SIVR represents the most cost-efficient route for investors who want to garner access to physical silver. However, given that SIVR is set up as a grantor trust, it remains susceptible to some tax inefficiencies, and its single metal focus also results in high volatility.

This article answers these three main questions about SIVR:

  • Who are the main players behind SIVR?
  • What type of investor is SIVR suitable for, and what are the risks associated with it?
  • What are some alternatives to SIVR?

data.title: Hertz: Making Some Progress (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Thursday morning, we received fourth-quarter results from Hertz (HTZ). The rental car company has been looking to turn around its business after a failed bet on electric vehicles led to significant losses. The latest results indicated that things are improving, but the company still faces a number of headwinds as we progress through 2026.

Previous Coverage of the Name

It was nearly a year ago that I last covered the company, right as the overall market was getting worried over President Trump's global tariff strategy. Hertz shares had jumped on hopes that rising used car prices would lower the company's depreciation expenses and lead to better resale values. However, things haven't worked out totally as expected, as since then, the stock has only risen about 6.7%, compared to a more than 24% surge in the S&P 500.

A Look at the Q4 Results and Recent News

For the final period of 2025, Hertz reported revenues of $2.028 billion. While this number was down $12 million over the prior year period, it did beat street estimates by about $100 million. The company reported a small increase in average rentable vehicles, but it had a slightly lower revenue per unit figure. While the International segment showed about 10% top-line growth, the much larger Americas division showed a 3% decline.

Hertz was able to narrow its losses quite a bit in the quarter, mainly due to a 21% drop in monthly depreciation per vehicle. The company also reduced its direct vehicle and operating expenses while also showing a decline in interest costs. However, the company still lost nearly $200 million, and this figure included a significant benefit from the reduction in the fair value of its public warrants. For the year, the net loss was $747 million.

In the current quarter, management expects a mid-single-digit revenue increase, well above the street's estimate for less than 2%. The company believes its commercial strategy is paying off, and it is focused on its off-airport and mobility business this year. I'll be curious to see if this progress continues later in 2026 as electric vehicle giant Tesla (TSLA) expands its robo-taxi network, which could be a headwind for the overall rental car industry.

The other major piece of news recently was a big loss for the company. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear a case regarding the company's bond payouts related to its Chapter 11 bankruptcy. As a result of this, the lower court's ruling stayed in place, so the company made a $346 million payment in January as detailed in its 10-K filing. The Delaware Bankruptcy Court will determine whether any additional amounts are due.

Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Update

Hertz finished 2025 with $565 million in cash on the balance sheet. However, due to the capital-intensive nature of the business, it also had over $17 billion in total debt. At nearly $16.5 billion, the net debt total worsened by almost three quarters of a billion dollars last year and is up more than $3.56 billion in the last three years alone.

The problem for Hertz right now is that it's not generating enough cash to cover the net costs of its capital expenditures. In 2025, total operating cash flow was $1.625 billion, down about $600 million from the year before. However, the company's net vehicle expenditures after disposals were about $2.1 billion, so true free cash flow was deeply negative. If things continue as is, Hertz will need to raise further capital through either debt or equity.

The Current Valuation Picture

With Hertz losing money currently, there is no price-to-earnings ratio to calculate here. On a price-to-sales basis, Hertz goes for about 0.18 times its currently expected revenues for this year. That's less than half the roughly 0.39 times that competitor Avis Budget Group (CAR) goes for. Hertz is projected to show more revenue growth in 2026, but Avis didn't lose as much money last year (after impairment charges).

On the analyst side of things, it's a mixed picture. Of the 9 analysts who have covered the stock in the past three months, there were six hold ratings and three sells. The current average price target is $4.75, implying more than 7% upside from current levels. That average has risen from $3.39 a year ago, but three years ago it was nearly $25.

Final Thoughts and Recommendation

As Hertz continues its turnaround efforts, Q4 revenues came in better than street estimates on Thursday. The quarter's decline wasn't nearly as bad as expected, and things are looking even better in the current period. The only problem here is that the business is very capital intensive, and the company isn't generating enough operating cash flow to cover its vehicle purchases, leading to a large and growing net debt pile.

Given the valuation seems very depressed now compared to a key industry peer, I'm upgrading the stock today from "Sell" to "Neutral." While I don't like the overall financial situation here, some progress has been made recently, and management did paint a pretty rosy picture for the start of this year. I'm not ready yet to fully buy in, given an ever-changing mobility industry, so I'd like to see another quarter or two of major progress here.

data.title: Salesforce's Q4 Proved AI Won't Kill Software - Still, I'm Not Buying The Dip Yet
data.description:
Here we have another software company busting the AI disruption fears that tanked the industry in the past few months. Salesforce, Inc. (CRM) just posted a blowout quarter, with Q4 revenue growing the most (12.1%) since the January 2023 quarter. On top of that, the company posted strong guidance, including double-digit growth in subscription & support revenue and projecting a CAGR of about 11% between 2026 and 2030, with a FY30 revenue target of $63B.

Perfect setup to buy the dip, right? I mean, we have a clear disconnect between fundamentals and price action. Do we?

Well, at 14.6x next year's earnings, I don't think the market is discontent with the valuation. Despite some bottom-line pressure due to token costs, fundamentals, guidance, and the Street's revenue models for the next few years are intact, but that doesn't mean the stock will recover in a V-shape form.

My concern is the lack of a clear catalyst to turn around the pessimism in the software space. To be clear, I don't see the recent panic selloff as capitulatory. Far from that.

Below, I explain why I'm staying on the sidelines with Salesforce.

Q4 Busted The AI Replaces Software Narrative

I'm going to start with the Q4 results first and leave the guidance and the Street's models for the end.

If there is one chart to temper down the AI disruption fears is the one below, representing the revenue growth in each quarter during the past few years.

Let me say it loud and clear: Salesforce posted its strongest quarter since January 2023!

Q4 revenue was $11.2B, up 12% y/y, while the subscription growth in FY26 was slightly above 10% y/y. So, the company is not losing any seats to companies developing their own CRM in-house.

On gross margins, the fourth quarter was still in the mid-70s%, significantly above the margins in 2023 or 2024.

The sequential decline since the July 2025 quarter makes sense, and it's actually (in my view) due to the Agentforce adoption momentum. Here is an excerpt from the last Q&A on the CFO's comments on margins (emphasis added):

I think you were asking specifically, Gabriela, about what does it do to gross margins? And as we think about margins in the short run, we think we're pretty neutral. Patrick talked about this differentiation between tokens and AWUs. Well, tokens, those prices, we're working with our various partners. Those are going to start to go down over time and commoditize.

I considered highlighting the last phrase. Let me explain why.

The demand for Agentforce is stronger than I initially expected. In its first 15 months, the company closed 29,000 deals for Agentforce (an AI-driven platform for building, deploying, and managing autonomous agents), with customers in production up 50% in Q4. On top of Agentforce, SlackBot is likely consuming a good amount of tokens as well, given that Slack hosts about 1 billion messages a day. I strongly believe the token usage is pressuring the bottom line of the company, as I don't believe Salesforce is passing through the entire cost of the tokens. As seen below, tokens are quite expensive.

I used Anthropic's (ANTHRO) API pricing model, as management seems to have a very good relationship with the AI startup.

One of those partners is in Great Anthropic, we love Anthropic, we love Dario, Daniela, I tweeted about what they did yesterday, incredible demo.

Just yesterday, Dario demonstrated how he is doing something amazing with Salesforce in the enterprise...... By the way, Anthropic runs its whole global operation on Salesforce and Slack, I think actually every AI company does. Yes, I think they do.

For comparison, here is OpenAI's API pricing model:

The reason I included the pricing model above is due to this statement from the CEO:

Today, we are one of the largest consumers of tokens in the world to date, now over 19 trillion tokens.

Assuming a 50-50% split of the 19T tokens between the input and output, and assuming no cached inputs, I get $16.6M in input costs and $133M in output costs for OpenAI's GPT 5.2 model. Using the Opus 4.6 model, I get $47.5M in input costs and 237.5M in output costs. Again, these numbers are conservative, as I'm assuming no cached inputs. The bottom line is that these costs are unlikely to be fully passed to customers. This may be the reason behind the small sequential decline in margins last year.

Moving on to another metric that busts the AI disruption fears, the CRPO in Q4 was $35.1B, up 16% YOY. In fact, if we look at the total RPO (which came in at $72B), the growth last quarter was the highest since the July 2024 quarter.

Call me crazy, but I don't see any AI disruptions. Which brings me to the guidance topic.

FY27 revenue guidance was between $45.8B–$46.2B, with a midpoint representing approximately 11% growth in constant currency. FY27 subscription and support growth guidance was slightly under 12% y/y on a nominal basis. On the bottom line, management expects a FY27 non-GAAP operating margin guidance of 34.3% (+20 bps) and GAAP operating margin of 20.9% (+80 bps).

Looking further ahead, management reiterated that it remains on track to hit the Rule of 50 by FY 2030. In fact, they are targeting a FY30 revenue target of $63B, which implies 11% CAGR between 2026 and 2030.

That's double-digit growth in the next 4 years. On top of that, the Street's revenue models have barely changed in the last 12 months.

In other words, even the Street is not buying the AI disruption narrative. If they did, we would have seen massive downward revisions to the chart above.

Valuation

In the past year, the P/E multiple has cooled off significantly from the high 40s at the start of 2025.

On a 1-year forward basis, Salesforce is trading at just 14.6x next year's earnings. Compared to its peers in the software space, that's a very attractive multiple.

In fact, it's the second cheapest in the group. That said, a cheap stock can remain cheap if there is no catalyst for a rerate ahead. Which brings me to the conclusion.

Looking Ahead

As I demonstrated in this article, the AI disruption fears in the software space are not real. Not only did Salesforce manage to report its best quarter in terms of revenue growth in years, but the guidance for FY26 and FY30 doesn't show any signs of deterioration. The Street hasn't downgraded its revenue models for the next 4 years, and that makes me think that no one really believes in the AI disruption narrative.

Who cares about fundamentals, right? The stock is down over 25% since the start of the year, which, at the end of the day, (despite intact fundamentals) is all that matters.

Unfortunately, I don't see the stock attractive from a price action perspective. The AI panic has led to the rupture of a critical support in the low $200s.

Despite intact fundamentals, the chart above looks anything but attractive. On top of that, the software application industry has been the worst performer in tech in the past 6-months and 1 year.

There may have been some improvements in software in the last week, but I don't see any clear signs of a turnaround in sentiment in this industry. Therefore, I prefer to stay on the sidelines for CRM and wait for a more favorable macro backdrop to buy the dip.

data.title: The State Of The Economy
data.description:
This is my "state of the U.S. economy" presentation.

I am not looking at or listening to what anyone else believes to be the state of the U.S. economy.

The first and most important part... I believe...is that the U.S. economy continues to grow at a relatively good pace.

In the fourth quarter of 2025, the year-over-year rate of growth of real GDP was 2.2 percent. Note that the fourth quarter of 2025 includes a shutdown in government spending due to the debates taking place in Washington, D.C.

The compound rate of growth of real GDP since the third quarter of 2009 was 2.5 percent.

The recessionary experience of 2020 in 2022 is attributed to the spread of COVID-19, followed by the shortest recession...two months...in U.S. history.

Even including this period of time in calculating the year-over-year rate of growth of the economy for the extended period of time does not drop the compound rate of growth for the whole period from 2.5 percent.

I have chosen this period out because Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke initiated a "new" approach to monetary policy that he introduced around the third quarter of 2009.

Bernanke's policy approach has been in place for the whole period of time.

Bernanke's approach has been for the Federal Reserve to choose a target for the Fed's outright purchase of securities for its portfolio.

The Federal Reserve engaged in three rounds of quantitative easing before the U.S. economy began to slow down and then one round of quantitative easing to combat the economic disruptions coming around the 2020-2022 period.

Then in March 2022, the Federal Reserve began a policy of quantitative tightening to combat the inflationary pressures that started following the Fed's very aggressive quantitative easing.

In December 2025, the Federal Reserve began another round of quantitative easing...a policy it is following at this time.

Bernanke's policy basically freed up the productive capabilities of the United States and sent the U.S. economy into a period of supply-side growth.

My argument has been, and I have written about this constantly during this period, that the economic growth achieved from the middle of 2009 on to the present time has been driven, not by demand-side spending, etc., but it has been driven by the supply-side of the economy.

Unemployment?

Well, unemployment has been running around 4.0 percent for much of this time period.

Here is the chart.

The latest unemployment rate, for December 2025, was 4.3 percent, down from 4.5 percent in November.

Obviously, the unemployment rate was disturbed by the economic turmoil in the 2020-2022 period, but note that the unemployment rate started to fall as the "Bernanke" policy was introduced in 2009 and fell and fell and fell up until the disturbance of 2020.

The unemployment rate dropped below 4.0 percent in the latter part of the 2010s.

And here we are in the mid-2020s. The unemployment rate dropped below 4.0 percent again, and although the rate has risen somewhat in the past year, it remains around the 4.0 percent level.

Many experts believe that this 4.0 percent rate can be assumed to be the "full" employment rate of unemployment.

In other words, employment seems to be holding its own in this period.

Inflation

Here we see the inflation rate as given by the Implicit Price Deflator coming from the Gross Domestic Product accounts.

As can be seen, the implicit prices have been rising at a relatively steady rate during this whole period, again the exception coming in the period of economic disturbance...2020-2022.

What can be seen in this chart is that during the time that the Federal Reserve followed the Bernanke approach to monetary policy, prices remained relatively stable, breaking out only during the period of economic disturbance.

We would like the rate of inflation to come lower. That is the goal of the Federal Reserve.

We need to keep our watch out on the Fed to see that it continues to exert itself to bring the rate of inflation down a little lower.

So, in the range of these three measures, the economy of the United States seems to be doing fairly well.

Economic growth...OK, around 2.5 percent. Unemployment...maybe a little high at 4.3 percent. Inflation...needs to be brought down closer to 2.0 percent.

What's wrong? What is driving discontent? What keeps people unhappy?

My answer to this is that over the past 40-45 years, the distribution of wealth in the United States has become much more skewed toward the higher income/wealth classes.

Here is how the lower 50 percent of the wealth distribution has performed over the past 50 years.

Now, here is the share of wealth owned by the top 1%.

How has this shift in the wealth distribution occurred?

Well, since 2009, we have had a Federal Reserve System, started under the leadership of Chairman Ben Bernanke, who considered that getting the stock market moving was a good start to raising the wealth of consumers. And, as the wealth of consumers rose, consumption spending would rise.

And, as consumer spending rose...the economy would grow.

Bernanke's policy worked on this chain of events.

Take a look at how the stock market has moved in the past 10 years or so.

However, the ownership of common stocks was not spread evenly across the board.

The wealthy owned stocks. And, as stock prices rose, the wealthy consumers gained more wealth. And the share of the wealth in the U.S. migrated more and more to the wealthy.

Bernanke's monetary policy has worked...and has worked very well in terms of economic growth, unemployment, and inflation.

But the income/wealth distribution in the United States became more and more centered in the wealthy classes.

And this has resulted in a lot of unrest and unhappiness in the county...it has impacted elections...and is a concern that needs public attention.

The state of the economy in the United States?

Pretty good.

But that "pretty good" has relied to a great extent on the performance of the Federal Reserve System and its policy of quantitative easing...and quantitative tightening.

There is really only one point of major discontent.

And, this issue is not really being discussed.

But the world moves on, and now we move into the period of saying "goodbye" to Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and begin to get used to the "new"...and this is a question mark right now... Fed Chairman is expected to be Kevin Warsh.

data.title: Super Micro's Billion-Dollar Stress Test (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
Investment Thesis

On the surface, Super Micro Computer (SMCI) appears to be the most straightforward read-through to the Nvidia AI supercycle. Since my last coverage, SMCI is up 10%, and with the strong quarter from Nvidia (NVDA) with revenue growth to record levels and Blackwell demand extending into next year, it is easy to believe that the company is simply a leveraged play on the demand for AI infrastructure.

However, underneath this hypergrowth, margins have compressed significantly to ~6% from 9.5% in Q1, indicating potential headwinds from customer concentration and supply issues. The investment thesis is contingent upon margin improvement and a shift in mix towards more value-infused infrastructure solutions.

Revenue is Real but Quality is More Important

There is no question about the revenue growth. Q2 revenue was $12.68 billion, significantly above guidance, and the company guided to at least $40 billion in revenue for the upcoming fiscal year. AI GPU platforms accounted for more than 90% of revenue, highlighting the company’s strong alignment with the Nvidia and AMD roadmaps.

However, the nature of the company’s revenue composition does require more scrutiny. For example, the company had one large data center customer that comprised about 63% of the company’s total revenue in the second quarter. This type of concentration, by itself, already poses considerable volatility risk. Although the company did signal that diversification efforts are underway, such high levels of concentration mean that the deployment timing of one single customer can already cause considerable volatility in the company’s results.

In terms of geographic dispersion, the company derived 86% of its revenue from the US, although Europe also declined considerably on a year-over-year basis. This also means that the company is likely seeing considerable hyperscale data center build-outs in the US, which are currently the primary drivers of the company’s business. However, if sovereign AI rollouts are undertaken in Europe and the Middle East, the company’s expanded manufacturing footprint in Malaysia, Taiwan, and the Netherlands also provides considerable leverage. However, the company’s primary source of revenue remains the large data center rollouts in the US.

What I find more interesting, however, is the company’s shift to Rack Scale Systems and the emergence of Data Center Building Block Solutions. Although not discussed in the company’s earnings call, the company did reveal that Data Center Building Block Solutions comprised about 4% of the company’s profit in the first half of FY2026, which could increase to double-digit profit contribution by the end of 2026. With the company’s gross margins on DCBBS already exceeding 20%, compared to the company’s mid-single-digit average, this is where the company’s business model really begins to change from one that is merely reselling hardware to one that is more integrated. However, this remains prospective and not actual.

Margin Compression: Temporary Friction or Structural Reality?

The major challenge in this quarter has been margin compression. The company has seen a decrease in its non-GAAP gross margin, now standing at 6.4%. The company has cited this as a result of customer mix, expedited transport costs, component shortages, and tariff effects. Some of these effects are likely cyclical in nature. The expedited transport cost for initial GP300 shipments will normalize over time.

Nevertheless, the customer mix is not entirely temporary. Large model builders and hyperscalers have enormous price leverage. When 63% of revenue comes from one customer, the bargaining dynamics are not symmetrical. Such structural pressure is exerted on the company’s margins unless there is substantial differentiation.

Operating expenses were impressively managed at 1.9% of revenue in the most recent quarter on a non-GAAP basis. This is indicative of substantial operating leverage. The company’s non-GAAP operating margins were at 4.5%, down from 5.4% in the prior quarter’s Q1. Nevertheless, such substantial scale is indicative of economies of scale. The pertinent question is whether these economies would be sufficient to offset the company’s gross margins in the mid-range.

The company’s free cash flow came in at negative $45 million due to the build-up in inventory to $10.6 billion and increased receivables. The cash conversion cycle has come down dramatically from 123 days to 54 days. Nevertheless, this is aided by the long payables cycle. The company’s net debt has increased to $787 million. Nevertheless, the company has secured multiple credit facilities aggregating to nearly $4 billion.

In my view, the company is in the land-grab phase. The company is deliberately accepting lower margins to acquire market share in the unprecedented AI infrastructure cycle. Such a strategy is workable provided the company’s higher-margin DCBBS and diversification into the enterprise segment are achieved quickly.

Platform Transition and Competitive Positioning

In the coming days, SMCI is gearing up to support Nvidia’s Vera Rubin platform as well as AMD’s Helios platform. The company is seeing strong visibility with customers for the second half. Historically, the company has prided itself on delivering total solutions to the marketplace several months before the reference architecture is available.

The underlying question is differentiation. Nvidia provides the underlying compute. SMCI provides the integration of compute, cooling, power, and rack-scale solutions. DCBBS is a natural extension of this, providing cooling distribution units, power shelves, battery backup, and data center management software.

This is a very strategically intelligent move for SMCI. Time to online is a very important factor for data center customers, and the same goes for increasing efficiencies around power consumption. If SMCI can successfully position itself as a one-stop shop for AI factory builders, not simply a server vendor, then its margin structure could improve significantly.

Valuation: Cheap for the Growth, Expensive for the Margins

At current multiples, SMCI is trading at a significant discount to its peers for FY2027 earnings, around 11x. On a forward P/S multiple, SMCI is also attractive at just 0.45x 2026 revenues, especially given its exposure to the AI trend.

However, the way to think about this name is not in isolation from its underlying margin structure. A 6% to 7% gross margin business deserves a very different multiple than a 20% to 30% infrastructure business. If the gross margin improves to the high single digits and DCBBS grows to a double-digit profit contribution, there could be significant earnings potential.

I see the valuation as fair. It assumes strong growth but not explosive margin growth. There is upside if DCBBS ramps up faster than expected. There is risk if hyperscaler pricing pressure continues.

Risks: When Hypergrowth Meets Hidden Fragility

What I see as the biggest risk is customer concentration. A change in deployment schedules by the 63% customer could introduce volatility in revenue and working capital. In a period with this much growth, visibility can change quickly.

Margin pressure could be more persistent than management expects. If component shortages continue or hyperscalers continue to pressure pricing, gross margin recovery could be slower than expected.

The inventory position of $10.6 billion is large. Management points to this as a position to take advantage of in the Q3 upswing. Any slowdown in demand could stress the company's working capital position. They have been proactive in increasing credit lines, and leverage is increasing.

Finally, the DOJ risk and corporate governance risk continue as an overhang. While the company is performing well operationally, investors could demand a risk premium until the corporate governance situation improves.

Takeaway

Super Micro is executing in the middle of the most powerful AI infrastructure in decades. They are growing revenue. They have excellent visibility in demand. However, I see margin risk and customer concentration risk. I see this as a Hold. I consider buying in at the insider levels provides speculative upside.

data.title: Super Micro: Margin Compression Has Caused The Market To Misprice The Stock
data.description:
Investment Thesis

Even though Super Micro Computer (SMCI) is one of the global leaders in the AI server segment, their ambitious goal of reaching $40 billion in revenue by 2026 faces a bunch of challenges. One of these is margin compression, since intense competition in the chosen segment is pushing net margins down to 3.1% from 6.9% a year earlier. This means SMCI's stock is dealing with what you might call a "growth quality crisis." In addition to analyzing Super Micro's growth drivers, competition, and financial profile, the purpose of this article is to assess its potential value and analyze key business risks in 2026. In spite of the challenges it faces, it has the potential to improve the operational and economic efficiency of its core business, allowing it to offset the loss of its previous margin and increase its market value. Meanwhile, its rapidly growing market and offering of more unique solutions for servers and data center cooling allow us to give SMCI shares a "Buy" rating.

SMCI's Strategy and Growth Drivers

As one of the global leaders in the high-performance server and data storage segment, Super Micro's role is growing in line with the ongoing AI supercycle and the development of related infrastructure. Its business portfolio includes three key areas: AI server solutions, liquid cooling technologies, and Building Block Solutions. AI servers are a key area for generating cash flow for SMCI, with the company developing and assembling server equipment optimized for use with graphics processing units, notably from NVIDIA (NVDA).

Within the first area, we have developed the Building Block Solutions concept, using a modular approach to building AI server architecture. An advantage of this product is the high speed of assembly of servers tailored to the individual configurations of each customer, ensuring the proper efficiency of the equipment in the future. DLC emerged separately from the development of AI servers; however, growing demand for the company's solutions is precisely due to the construction of new data centers. Operating chips in their infrastructure generates a huge amount of heat, which SMCI's liquid cooling systems allow centers to operate more efficiently and without unexpected shutdowns and failures. Furthermore, implementation of the company's DLC reduces energy costs for the cooling system itself and enables more chips and computing power to be placed in a smaller data center footprint.

In analyzing the catalysts for SMCI's strategic growth in 2026, we should point out the main short-term driver related to NVIDIA's Blackwell update. The data shows that at the beginning of 2026, its order book for these systems is around $13 billion. That's thanks to Building Block Solutions, where it can get ready-made servers based on these chips up and running about a month faster than its competitors, and that's a key thing in the race between hyperscalers. In addition to the driver from the Blackwell update, another important growth catalyst for SMCI is the increasing demand for highly efficient liquid cooling systems. It is because chips are becoming more powerful than 1000 W, and traditional cooling mechanisms are physically unable to cope with this. Right now, this company has set up the world's largest production of liquid-cooled racks (with up to 5000 racks per month), allowing it to keep up with growing demand. The global cooling systems market is expected to reach $21 billion in revenue by 2026, growing to $54 billion by 2034, estimates Fortune Business. Around 35% of all spending on cooling components is related to AI computing infrastructure.

Given that SMCI's main challenge is the contraction of its marginal business, investments in the launch of more cost-effective production facilities are emerging as key growth drivers. This includes the launch of a new plant in Malaysia, expected to take place in the second half of 2026. Economic benefits of the project will be reflected in lower costs, particularly labor and taxes (when compared to the US and Taiwan). Moreover, SMCI's management expects the launch of this plant to boost revenue to $40 billion in 2026. The increase in revenue will be accompanied by economies of scale, with even a minimal improvement in operating efficiency from lower costs significantly improving EPS.

Competition for SMCI

Analyzing SMCI's competitive environment, we should understand that the company faces competition in the production of servers for AI infrastructure and liquid cooling systems. The competition can be classified into 3 key groups: global technology giants, Asian players, and indirect competitors.

Groups of global technology giants are SMCI's most direct competitors, since they are all fighting for orders from large enterprises and government agencies. Dell Technologies (DELL) will be the main competitor, currently pursuing an aggressive policy to capture an increasing share of the AI server market. For this purpose, the company is leveraging its huge corporate customer base and the best global supply chain. The other global competitor from the US is Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), with competitive advantages in the high-performance computing segment. By acquiring Juniper Networks, it strengthened its position in AI networking solutions, which allows it to offer data centers more comprehensive infrastructure packages.

A group of Asian players is led by technology giant Lenovo Group. The company focuses on hybrid cloud solutions and offers more flexible pricing, one of the main reasons for the decline in margins for SMCI and other US companies. Asian competitors also include Inspur (the largest server manufacturer in China, which dominates the domestic market) and Giga Computing (providing solutions for custom GPU servers and developing solutions to support new NVIDIA and AMD chips). ASUS and Foxconn are also worth mentioning among Asian players, however, as they often act as contract manufacturers. Their main target audience is the lower and middle price segments. Generally speaking, the common characteristic of all Asian competitors is their cheaper offerings, due to lower production costs resulting from economies of scale.

Indirect competitors include hyperscalers, such as Amazon, Google, and Microsoft, that are not only major customers for SMCI's AI servers and cooling systems but also engage in their own internal development. In fact, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are developing their own server architectures for their own chips (Trainium, Inferentia, TPU, and Maia). Their goal is to make hyperscalers less dependent on outside contractors, particularly since most of the manufacturers are in Asia.

Looking at the future of competition, the total revenue for the server market hit another record high of $112.4 billion in Q3 2025. Plus, suppliers' revenue went up 61% compared to Q3 2024. The US remains the main server market, growing by 79.1%, compared to China's more modest growth of 37.6%. Analyzing the structure of the competition, note that Dell remains the main player in the server market, accounting for 8.3% of the market, compared to 9.7% a year earlier. Meanwhile, SMCI is the second-largest company in the world in terms of sales of OEM products for servers, with revenue falling by 13.2%, reflecting the impact of margin compression. While SMCI's share was 7.4% a year earlier, today it is only 4.0%. Moreover, previously, the top 5 companies accounted for 33.3% of the server market, and now they account for 22.6%. The decline in the concentration of key manufacturers in the market is caused by the emergence of an increasing number of local competitors and newcomers from Asia, as well as the internal developments of hyperscalers.

SMCI's Financial Profile

The financial profile of SMCI's business appeals to me because the company is showing positive momentum in revenue and EPS, which proves that it is capable of not only spending investors' capital but also generating profits. SMCI's status as a key partner of NVIDIA (63% of total revenue) allows it to scale its business, expand production, and move towards supplying individual servers with higher added value. About 84% of the company's total revenue comes from the US domestic market. Nevertheless, even with solid revenue growth, they're dealing with shrinking business margins. As of now, net margins have dropped to 3.1% and gross margins to 6.4%. By comparison, the latter was 11.8% a year earlier. Operating cash flow was negative at $24 million, down $240 million from the same period a year earlier.

Looking at the company's latest financial report, we should point out that non-GAAP EPS was $0.69, up $0.20 from the consensus forecast, and revenue was $2.36 billion higher than expected, coming in at $12.7 billion. That's up 122.8% from the same period a year earlier, leading to an increase in the company's forecasts for 2026. Around 90% of SMCI's revenue will continue to come from sales of AI cluster solutions, allowing it to achieve an annual revenue of $36-40 billion.

SMCI Valuation

In order to assess the potential value of SMCI shares, we must take into account that using only traditional P/E multiples is unreasonable, given the company's high CAPEX costs. It is therefore worth looking at other multiples, among which are EV/Sales and EV/EBITDA. SMCI Risks

The main risks to Super Micro's market value growth are still structural issues within the company. Let's break them down into three categories:

  • The critical concentration of customers in the revenue structure, with approximately 63% of all revenue coming from one major customer.   • Marginal business compression, resulting in significantly lower potential net profit growth. That said, factors like building a new factory, a 42.9% discount on the EV/Sales multiple, and the Building Block Solutions offering will help the company be more competitive by improving quality instead of dumping prices.
